review.title: Generating extrema approximation of analytically incomputable functions through usage of parallel computer aided genetic algorithms
review.abstract: This paper presents capabilities of using genetic algorithms to find approximations of function extrema, which cannot be found using analytic ways. To enhance effectiveness of calculations, algorithm has been parallelized using OpenMP library. We gained much increase in speed on platforms using multithreaded processors with shared memory free access. During analysis we used different modifications of genetic operator, using them we obtained varied evolution process of potential solutions. Results allow to choose best methods among many applied in genetic algorithms and observation of acceleration on Yorkfield, Bloomfield, Westmere-EX and most recent Sandy Bridge cores.

metadata.title: GENERATING EXTREMA APPROXIMATION OF ANALYTICALLY INCOMPUTABLE FUNCTIONS THROUGH USAGE OF PARALLEL COMPUTER AIDED GENETIC ALGORITHMS

sections.heading: GENERATING EXTREMA APPROXIMATION OF ANALYTICALLY INCOMPUTABLE FUNCTIONS THROUGH USAGE OF PARALLEL COMPUTER AIDED GENETIC ALGORITHMS
sections.text: Lukasz Swierczewskiluk.swierczewski @ gmail.com Computer Science and Automation Institute, College of Computer Science and BusinessAdministration in Lomza, PolandIn this paper, possibilities are presented to use genetic algorithms to find approximate values of the function extrema, which cannot be found by analytical means. In order to increase the effectiveness of the calculations, the algorithm was paralleled with the help of the OpenMP library. We have gained considerable speed on platforms with multi-threaded processors with shared memory access. In the analysis, we have used various modifications of the genetic operator, with which we obtain different evolutionary processes of potential solutions.The results allow to select the best from many methods used in genetic algorithms and to observe the acceleration on Yorkfield, Bloomfield, Westmere-EX and the most recent Sandy Bridge cores.Keywords: artificial intelligence, genetic algorithms, parallel algorithms, extreme functional algorithms

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: Genetic Algorithm (GA) is a type of algorithm inspired by the evolution of living organisms in nature. It is one of the evolutionary algorithms whose idea was initiated by John Henry Holland, the American engineer and scientist. GA searches in a specific way in the area of solving a problem to find the best solution. GA defines the environment in which a specific population of specimens represents possible solutions to the problem. Furthermore, similar to organisms in nature, the specimens are crossed, mutated and the selection of the best solutions is based on the value of the adaptation function. Ideas of the genetic algorithm are presented in the illustration.

sections.heading: Algorithm
sections.text: The implementation of GA, which is described and presented in the thesis, is a fragment of the Olib library. Its sources written in C / C + + language are available at [3] address. In the genetic algorithm, the following crossing methods were implemented: • single-point crossover, • two-point crossover, • uniform crossover (mixing ratio = 0.5), • uniform crossover (random mixing ratio), • semi-uniform crossover, • arithmetic crossover (functions: AND, OR, NOR, NAND, XOR, Random) One-point crossover method was implemented in two ways. In the first implementation, if the result is exceeded, there is always a child. In the second implementation, with 2 / 3 probability, a child is born, with 2 / 9 probability, two children and with 1 / 9 probability, three children.

sections.heading: Realization calculations
sections.text: In recent years, it has become clear that most of them are people who are incapable of defending their interests.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text: Genetic operators analyzed in the article can be divided into more and less sophisticated methods in terms of the operations performed. In terms of intersections, the Uniform Crossover implementation proved to be the most complex, and in terms of the selection of this tournament method, the complexity of which increases with the increasing size of the tournament group. Genetic algorithms go through relatively well parallel processes. Acceleration is quite noticeable on modern multi-core processors. In the case of more advanced platforms, which are composed of many multi-core processors, problems with appropriate performance scaling may arify. Applying with programmable graphical accelerators, which have become very popular in recent years, can prove to be a very interesting prospect. If used properly, they will certainly enable even faster processing of data.

sections.heading: Acknowledgment
sections.text: The work was prepared with the supercomputer resources of the Faculty of Mathematics, Physics and Computer Science of the Maria Curie Skłodowska University in Lublin and the Institute of Computer Science and Automation of the College of Computer Science and Business Administration in Lomza.
